doc.after: Several cyanide complexes are known. The most famous example is Prussian blue, (Fe4(Fe[CN]6)3). Potassium ferricyanide and potassium ferrocyanide are also known; the formation of Prussian blue upon reaction with iron(II) and iron(III) respectively forms the basis of a "wet" chemical test.[27] Prussian blue is also used as an antidote for thallium and radioactive caesium poisoning.[31][32] Prussian blue can be used in laundry bluing to correct the yellowish tint left by ferrous salts in water.
